text.headline: Phylogenetics in real time
text.text: Open science, data sharing, and the Wuhan coronavirus outbreak

text.headline: Initial reports of viral pneumonia
text.text: 27 reported cases of pneumonia related to a seafood market in Wuhan are determined to have a viral cause.  Influenza A virus, respiratory syncytial virus and SARS coronavirus are soon ruled out.

text.headline: Initial release of genome sequence
text.text: The genome sequence is immediately released to the public. Preliminary analysis indicates it is most closely related to bat SARS-coronaviruses.

text.headline: Additional genomes released
text.text: Five new genomes are produced by three different labs and deposited in the open access GISAID database.  Researchers begin to post their analysis results on http://virological.org

text.headline: A recombinant origin discovered
text.text: Researchers release initial findings that the Wuhan coronavirus is a recombinant of multiple bat coronavirus genomes.

text.headline: A single origin mapped to mid-December 2019
text.text: There is now enough sequences to estimate the rate of evolution, which makes it possible to date the ancestor of genomes that have been sampled so far.  Several groups announce their estimates on virological.org.

text.headline: Estimated R0 at ~2.6 new cases per infection
text.text: Multiple groups release preprints reporting their estimates of R0 on bioRxiv and medRxiv. Misleading interpretations of early estimates spread on social media. Phylodynamic estimates likely in the next week.

text.headline: Real-time, open source phylogenetics
text.text: Nextstrain (http://nextstrain.org/ncov) releases an interactive web document that updates in real time as additional genomes are released.  The developers partner with scientists in China to translate these documents into Chinese.
